prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Characterizing Protostellar Morphology
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Protostellar collapse morphology will be characterized by: a) ALMA Band 7 continuum measurements of the protostellar infall envelope morpology and b) maps of molecular outflows made by observing the 12CO J=3-2 line.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Technical Justification:
To test predictions of magnetically regulated star formation during early stages of protostellar collapse we require A) continuum observations of inner core morphologies which clearly resolve the orientation of the major axis and B) measurements of outflow direction near the protostar.
Receiver: Band 7. It has excellent sensitivity to dust emission, the bright line CO J=3-2 as an outflow tracer, and can provide full coverage of a Class 0/I source in a single ALMA pointing.
Imaging: To clearly measure elongation of inner cores (typical sizes ~1,000-6,000 AU, see Chapman et al., 2013), we require a resolution of 500 AU (0.7’’), and use of the ACA for sensitivity to scales larger than 5000 AU (7’’). Using the 12m array, ACA and TP array, core morphology can be measured on 0.7’’-17’’ (500 – 12,000 AU) scales. To test our configuration we simulated ALMA observations using SHARC-II CSO observations of the Class 0 source IC 348-SMM2 at 300 pc (Davidson et al., 2011). The left panel of Figure 2 shows the SHARC map of the elongated ~5,000 AU inner core. The right panel shows the ALMA observation made using the CASA simalma task, which recovers the elongated structure.
Correlator Setup: Baseband 4 will be used to detect outflows in CO J=3-2 (345.79599 GHz). We will use the 937.5 MHz bandwidth setup with 488.281 kHz (0.423 km/s) per channel resolution, and for most sources we will smooth our data to 976.563 kHz resolution. The linewidths of outflows are typically 3-5 km/s, so 0.847 km/s (976.563 kHz) resolution is sufficient. This baseband setup will allow us the flexibility to use the higher spectral resolution (0.423 km/s) for bright outflows. The other three basebands will be used for continuum observations (2000 MHz bandwidth, 31.250 MHz resolution).
Sensitivity Required: A) Continuum: Most of our targets are likely Class 0 sources, but we also have two Class I sources. 2.7 mm observations of the Class 0 source B335 (Chandler & Sargent, 1993) at 2.9" x 2.7" (~700 AU) resolution show elongated structure with the major axis > 1000 AU. We scale the peak flux of 24 mJy/beam to 0.87 mm to obtain 720 mJy/beam, which scaled to the distance of Vela C and 0.7’’ beam size corresponds to 40 mJy/beam. For Class I objects we use as an analog the ~725x225AU source Elias 29 (d=125 pc), which has a total flux of 109mJy at 1.1mm (Jorgensen et al., 2009). Scaling to 0.87mm we obtain a flux of 220 mJy, which corresponds 7.0 mJy at the distance of Vela C and 5.0 mJy/beam for a 0.7’’ beam. We require an RMS 20 times less than this level (RMS=0.25 mJy/beam).
B) Line CO J=3-2: We use CO J=2-1 SMA observations of the outflow in the very young source Per Bolo 51 from Dunham et al. (2011) for our estimates. A per channel (0.847 km/s) RMS level of 0.23 K would adequately detect the outflow.
Yildiz et al. (2012) found particle densities of 10,000 to 100,000 cm^-3 and excitation temperatures of 100-200 K for outflows from Class 0 objects. Using the RADEX radiative transfer code (Van der Tak et al., 2007), the CO J=3-2 line should be at least as bright as the J=2-1 line, so we take ~0.23 K as an appropriate per channel RMS for our ALMA CO J=3-2 observations. As the SMA beam for Per Bolo 1 (730x623 AU) is larger than our ALMA beam, the equivalent per channel RMS should also be 0.23 K (11 mJy/beam) for our ALMA observations.
Observing Time Request: Set by the CO J=3-2 observations: for a 976.563 MHz channel width, a per channel RMS limit of = 0.23 K (11 mJy/beam), the ALMA OT gives a per source 12m array observing time of 3.22 min, which for all 13 targets + calibrations and overheads = 1.53 hours. An additional 6.12 hours is required for the ACA + TP measurements for a total requested time of 7.65 hours.
For continuum observations an observing time of 3.22 minutes per source over a 6GHz bandwidth gives an RMS of 0.15 mJy/beam, which is below the required 0.25 mJy/beam.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The role of magnetic fields in the collapse of molecular cloud cores is a topic of ardent controversy. We propose to combine a) the world's most detailed GMC magnetic field map - a balloon-borne observation of Vela C derived from many thousands of submillimeter polarization measurements (from "BLASTPol") - with b) exquisitely sensitive high resolution maps such as only ALMA can make for 13 protostars in this cloud. In particular, we propose ALMA Band 7 observations of both the dust continuum, for mapping inner core morphology, and the 12CO J=3-2 line, for mapping bipolar outflows. We will map structures on 500 - 12,000 AU scales, for the cloud distance of 700 pc. Vela C is believed to be a rich star forming environment at a very early evolutionary stage, and we have used Herschel and WISE data to select the youngest protostars. We will determine the degree of correlation between outflow axes, orientations of flattened infall envelopes, and cloud magnetic field directions, thereby providing definitive tests of competing theoretical models. Our observations will require 7.7 hours of ALMA time (1.5 hours on the 12m array and 6.1 hours on the Compact and Total Power arrays).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00531.S, Title: "Joint ALMA and BLASTPol Constraints on Protostellar Infall Morphologies and Cloud Magnetci icelds", PI: Haggard, D. 2011.0.00488.S, Title: "Joint ALMA and BLASTPol Constraints on Protostellar Infall Morphologies and Cloud Magnetic Fields", PI: Haggard, D.
